I've tried to glean information on the problem from other bug posts, but nothing
I've tried has cured my problem.  I've got some experience with pre-built Apache
servers, but I haven't ever tried to compile anything other than the default
install before.
creator: pjohanneson@gmail.com
bnicholes@apache.org
text:
Building against the Novell LDAP SDK on Linux has never been very well test 
nor is it necessary.  Try building against the OpenLDAP libraries.

That looks like a permission problem to me. Are you sure that you have the
correct file permissions set on /tmp/apache2/httpd-2.2.0 and all its subdirs
(including the hidden .libs dirs)?
creator: rpluem@apache.org
pjohanneson@gmail.com
text:
bnicholes@apache.org:
I'll try that.  I was using the Novell one since our LDAP stuff is on a Novell
server.

Ruediger Pluem:
I'm running it in a "sudo" shell/container/whatever; would that not give me
ample permissions?  If not, I can su to root.

(In reply to comment #3)
> bnicholes@apache.org:
> I'll try that.  I was using the Novell one since our LDAP stuff is on a 
Novell
> server.

Which backend LDAP server you are hitting doesn't make a difference on which 
LDAP client SDK that you use.  My backend LDAP server is also Novell LDAP 
running on a NetWare server.  When I build httpd for NetWare I use the NetWare 
LDAP client and when I build httpd for Linux I use OpenLDAP.  Both are able to 
access the NetWare LDAP server without any problem.
creator: bnicholes@apache.org
rpluem@apache.org
text:
> Ruediger Pluem:
> I'm running it in a "sudo" shell/container/whatever; would that not give me
> ample permissions?  If not, I can su to root.

Maybe I get things wrong, but I am currently talking about compiling httpd and
not running it. Do you even compile httpd in a sudo shell?
Anyway the question remains to me why we see the "permission denied" messages in
your output. It seems to be that this causes make to stop.

Here's the latest attempt.

creator: pjohanneson@gmail.com
rpluem@apache.org
text:
Fine, the permission problem is now gone. I miss a lot of checks in your output
from "Configuring Apache Portable Runtime Utility library". Especially the
checks for the LDAP libraries are missing. I assume that apr-util does not
detect your LDAP SDK.

creator: pjohanneson@gmail.com
text:
Bear in mind that I've never compiled Apache before -- is apr-util part of the
default Apache compile?  If not, is it something that I have to install separately?

I've just tried again, with the openldap libraries and utilities, and I get
largely the same results.

Delete your build tree (as root).  Clearly there are stale issues here.

  As yourself, unpack the tarball and start fresh all over again.  It seems
  you keep tripping over the previous (successful) bits of configuration,
  causing the full reconfigure and rebuild to fail.

  httpd tarballs include srclib/apr/ and srclib/apr-util/ and should configure
  those, unless you installed them independently into your system.  If that's
  the case you have to rerun those standalone configure/build steps to include
  your LDAP SDK.

  This really isn't reflecting any bugs in the packages, but numerous misconf
  snafus - I suggest you consult a users list (after attempting the steps
  above) for additional help about your particular environment.
creator: wrowe@apache.org
